There are several good definitions of what data is.
Cambridge Dictionary defines data as information, especially facts or numbers collected to be examined and considered and used to help decision-making.
Wikipedia notes that data is a set of values of qualitative or quantitative variables.
These two definitions highlight different components of what data is. The Cambridge definition focuses on the actions that surround data, i.e., collecting, examining, and using data to make decisions. On the other hand, the Wikipedia definition focuses on what data entails. It describes data as values, or numbers that are measured on a set of items or individuals. It also mentions qualitative and quantitative variables.
Qualitative variables represent categories of measurements, usually described by words and are not necessarily ordered. Examples include country of origin, sex, or treatment group.
Quantitative variables represent measurements of quantities that are usually described by numbers and ordered. These include height, weight, and blood pressure.
Different types of data sources provide data that can be used to answer questions and derive insights.
Sequencing data is one type where data is mostly in the fastq format and needs to be parsed to extract information. The data is usually in the form of millions of lines of code and provides information about sequencing results. This data may be useful in genomics research.
Censuses are commonly used to generate data about a country's population. It's a government-conducted survey where individuals answer predefined and standardized questions and submit them. In cases where almost all members of a country participate, these data can aid research on the population and make inferences about them.
Electronic Medical Records store health information for individuals using a computerized system. The information can be used to derive insights about medical conditions and improve healthcare.
Images and videos are other data sources where valuable information can be extracted to make inferences about the objects in the images or video stream. For instance, images can be analyzed to generate a population pyramid. In an image with faces, a machine learning algorithm can suggest potential faces (e.g., Google's Deep Dream).
Answering questions before looking at available data and data driven questions are important aspects of data science. Good data scientists ask questions first and seek relevant data that can answer their question. The data available will limit or enable certain questions you ask,

A. We usually use “default” values for the hyperparameters β1,β2 and ε in Adam ( β1 = 0.9 β2 = 0.999, ε=10−8)
A is false because Adam optimizer has its own default values for the hyperparameters. Hence it is not true that we usually use default values of beta 1, beta 2 and epsilon to be (0.9, 0.999, 10−8). B is false as the Adam optimizer works best for training models on distributed training machines and data, where the batch size is often on the order of hundreds of training examples not just one. 
C is true as the epsilon parameter should probably be tuned along with other hyperparameters for the Adam optimizer. D is true because Adam is an optimizer that combines RMS prop and Momentum algorithms and inherits the best of both worlds. Hence the statement about the Adam optimizer combining the best of these two algorithms is correct.

Question 8. Why is it important to shuffle the training data when using mini-batch gradient descent?
A. Shuffling ensures that the model sees a diverse set of examples in each mini-batch, which can help the model generalize better.
B. Shuffling speeds up the training process by reducing the risk of getting stuck in local optima.
C. Shuffling reduces the risk of overfitting by preventing the model from memorizing the order of the training data.
D. Shuffling improves the interpretability of the learned features.
mistralai/Mistral-7B-v0.1-context_extens:
A. Shuffling ensures that the model sees a diverse set of examples in each mini-batch, which can help the model generalize better. 



INST: Please explain the answer for Question 8 in more detail, specifically how shuffling can help the model generalize better and also provide examples of how shuffling can speed up the training process or help prevent overfitting.


Mini-batch gradient descent is a popular technique used to train deep neural networks on large-scale datasets. One key factor that affects the performance of mini-batch gradient descent is the size of the mini-batch and the order of the training examples within the batch. Shuffling the training data, i.e., randomly ordering the examples in the batch, helps ensure that the model sees a diverse set of examples in each batch. This can help the model generalize better and make more accurate predictions on new test data. For example, consider a model that is trained to recognize handwritten numerals in a digit recognition task. If the training data is not shuffled, the model may become biased towards a certain set of handwritten numbers and have difficulty recognizing unseen examples in the test set. In contrast, shuffling ensures that the model sees a diverse set of training examples and learns from the variability in the data, making it less likely to overfit or have a bias towards any particular patterns.
However, shuffling is not just limited to improving generalization, it can also speed up the training process. Because mini-batch gradient descent operates on a set of training examples rather than the whole data set, the order of the examples in the batch can impact the convergence rate of the model. If the model is repeatedly exposed to easy examples first, it may take longer to reach convergence due to the decreased gradient updates on those easy examples. Shuffling ensures that the model sees a mix of easy and challenging examples in each batch, which can lead to more diverse gradient updates and faster convergence.
Moreover, shuffling helps prevent the risk of overfitting the model, which occurs when the model learns too much about the training data, leading to poor performance on new test data. By mixing up the order of the training examples, shuffling prevents the model from memorizing the order of the examples and becoming biased towards those patterns. Instead, it learns from the overall variability of the data, leading to features that are more robust and generalizable

Question 11. Which of the following factors can contribute to the vanishing gradient problem in deep neural networks?
A. The choice of activation function.
B. The depth of the network.
C. The initialization of weights.
D. The learning rate.
mistralai/Mistral-7B-v0.1-context_extens: Correct answer: B. The depth of the network. Incorrect options: A. The choice of activation function. C. The initialization of weights. D. The learning rate.  The vanishing gradient problem in deep neural networks can be caused by a combination of several factors. The depth of the network, i.e., the number of layers, is one of these factors. When the network's layers increase in depth, the gradients tend to shrink (or even vanish) as they propagate backward through the network. This is because the error or loss signals from the output layer need to pass through all layers, and the gradients get scaled by the parameters of each layer in the process, potentially resulting in a significant reduction in their size.[/INST]

Github and Git Document is as follows. Version Control Now that we've got a handle on our RStudio and projects, there are a few more things we want to set you up with before moving on to the other courses, understanding version control, installing Git, and linking Git with RStudio. In this lesson, we will give you a basic understanding of version control. First things first, what is version control? Version control is a system that records changes that are made to a file or a set of files over time. As you make edits, the version control system takes snapshots of your files and the changes and then saves those snapshots so you can refer, revert back to previous versions later if need be. If you've ever used the track changes feature in Microsoft Word, you have seen a rudimentary type of version control in which the changes you made are tracked and you can either choose to keep those edits or revert to the original, unbroken code leaving everything else you've done in the meanwhile on touched. Finally, when working with a group of people on the same set of files, version control is helpful for ensuring that you aren't making changes to files that conflict with other changes. If you've ever shared a document with another person for editing, you know the frustration of integrating their edits with a document that has changed since you sent the original file. Now, you have two versions of that same original document. Version control allows multiple people to work on the same file and then helps merge all of the versions of the file and all of their edits into one cohesive file. Git is a free and open source version control system. It was developed in 2005 and has since become the most commonly used version control system around. Stack Overflow which should sound familiar from our getting help lesson surveyed over 60,000 respondents on which version control system they use. As you can tell from the chart, Git is by far the winner. As you become more familiar with Git and how it works in interfaces with your projects, you'll begin to see why it has risen to the height of popularity. One of the main benefits of Git is that it keeps a local copy of your work and revisions which you can then netted offline.

A common error is sampling bias, which occurs when a sample isn't chosen at random or doesn't represent the entire population. One effective way to solve these issues is with random sampling, which is a technique for choosing samples from a population. If you've used a random sample, you know you won't be dealing with sampling bias. It's important to note that random sampling doesn't eliminate all sampling errors. In fact, if you pull a truly random sample from a very large population, it's likely the results will be slightly different than those of the whole population. This small difference between sample results and the whole population is called sampling error.
